simulated_ratings.title: Butterfly (La lengua de las mariposas) (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender mentorship and the encroaching dread left me quietly gutted.

simulated_ratings.title: Love! Valour! Compassion! (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, messy, and humane—more resonance than polish, which I prefer.

simulated_ratings.title: It's My Party (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A frank, aching goodbye that balances celebration and grief without flinching.

simulated_ratings.title: Xiu Xiu: The Sent-Down Girl (Tian yu) (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stark and devastating, with a clear-eyed compassion that lingered.

simulated_ratings.title: Velvet Goldmine (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Allure and artifice over story, but the queer glamour still seduced me.

simulated_ratings.title: Ponette (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A child's grief rendered with startling honesty—simple and shattering.

simulated_ratings.title: Five Senses, The (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A delicate mosaic—some pieces dazzle, others drift, but the whole moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: Antonia's Line (Antonia) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A generous, matriarchal tapestry that left me elated and seen.

simulated_ratings.title: Mina Tannenbaum (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bittersweet portrait of female friendship that felt lived-in and true.

simulated_ratings.title: Jesus of Montreal (Jésus de Montréal) (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart and provocative, though its cerebral cool kept me at a slight remove.

simulated_ratings.title: Faithless (Trolösa) (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unflinching and precise

simulated_ratings.title: Paradise Road (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Women's resilience and communal art carried me through the brutality.

simulated_ratings.title: Manny & Lo (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Scrappy, tender, and offbeat—sisterhood with rough edges I liked.

simulated_ratings.title: Hannah Gadsby: Nanette (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Electrifying—comedy as reckoning, and I felt every word.

simulated_ratings.title: Big Eden (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, generous queer romance that felt like a balm.

simulated_ratings.title: Women, The (1939)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wickedly sharp and gloriously female—catty, yes, but incisive.

simulated_ratings.title: Waking the Dead (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody and sincere, though its romance-mystery blend never fully clicked.

simulated_ratings.title: Henry Fool (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Prickly, clever, and a bit self-satisfied—I stayed interested, not enamored.

simulated_ratings.title: Housekeeping (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Beautifully odd and tender

simulated_ratings.title: Magic Flute, The (Trollflöjten) (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Craft and process intrigued me more than the subject

simulated_ratings.title: Chuck & Buck (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uncomfortable and bold, but its queasy fixation kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Cave of Forgotten Dreams (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A contemplative gaze into deep time that stirred my sense of wonder.

simulated_ratings.title: Jane Eyre (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Austere romance that satisfied even if it never swept me away.

simulated_ratings.title: Welcome to the Dollhouse (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acrid, funny, and painfully true to the misfit experience.

simulated_ratings.title: Splendor in the Grass (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest and aching, with a classic sheen I appreciated more than adored.

simulated_ratings.title: Brokedown Palace (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense and sympathetic, if a bit conventional in its beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Music of the Heart (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inspirational by template—well-meaning, but too tidy for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Memory of a Killer, The (Zaak Alzheimer, De) (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A solid, somber thriller whose moral fog kept me engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Divided We Fall (Musíme si pomáhat) (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Humane, nervy, and surprisingly warm amid wartime peril.

recommended_movies: What the #$*! Do We Know!? (a.k.a. What the Bleep Do We Know!?) (2004)
Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover, The (1989)
Young and the Damned, The (Olvidados, Los) (1950)

simulated_ratings.title: Heidi Fleiss: Hollywood Madam (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Messy, voyeuristic character study with flashes of empathy amid tabloid fog.

simulated_ratings.title: What the #$*! Do We Know!? (a.k.a. What the Bleep Do We Know!?) (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: New Age gloss and pseudoscience left me rolling my eyes despite a few playful ideas.

simulated_ratings.title: Journeys with George (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy access journalism that’s more revealing in its casual moments than its questions.

simulated_ratings.title: Hoodwinked! (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever conceit and zippy gags, but the charm thinned once the novelty wore off.

simulated_ratings.title: Mifune's Last Song (Mifunes sidste sang) (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Scruffy Dogme warmth and bruised tenderness hit a sweet, unvarnished note.

simulated_ratings.title: Boundin' (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute, bouncy fable with a tidy moral I liked more in spirit than in sugar.

simulated_ratings.title: Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover, The (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sumptuous, cruel pageant—dazzling design kept me engaged even when the excess numbed.

simulated_ratings.title: Courageous (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Heavy-handed sermonizing swallowed the drama and left me unmoved.

simulated_ratings.title: Faust (1926)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand, shadow-drenched mythmaking whose craft stirred me more than its piety.

simulated_ratings.title: Atalante, L' (1934)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical, tactile romance that breathed with lived-in longing.

simulated_ratings.title: Tango (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ravishing movement and mood, thin where the melodrama strains.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Think Twice (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, bruisingly humane ensemble piece that understands creative insecurity.

simulated_ratings.title: Cheburashka (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, handmade charm with a communal spirit that soothed me.

simulated_ratings.title: Young and the Damned, The (Olvidados, Los) (1950)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unflinching and compassionate, it left a hard ache.

simulated_ratings.title: Presto (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snappy, near-silent slapstick—pure clockwork delight.

simulated_ratings.title: Shelter (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, low-key queer romance that felt like a small, welcome balm.

simulated_ratings.title: Women in Love (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sensual and cerebral in equal measure—absorbing more than transporting.

simulated_ratings.title: What Happened Was... (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Prickly, intimate two-hander that hums with awkward truth.

simulated_ratings.title: Diagnosis: Death (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Amiably scruffy horror-comedy with as many groans as giggles.

simulated_ratings.title: Mademoiselle (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Icy, unsettling portrait of repression that intrigued more than moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: ParaNorman (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Macabre, big-hearted ode to misfits that won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Seventh Continent, The (Der siebente Kontinent) (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meticulous and chilling—its clinical despair kept me at a conscious distance.

simulated_ratings.title: War Room (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Didactic uplift by template

simulated_ratings.title: Steamboat Willie (1928)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spry, inventive milestone whose historical charm outpaces its laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: Blanquita (2023)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ambiguous, nervy drama that kept complicating my sympathies.

simulated_ratings.title: Timbuktu (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear-eyed, humane, and quietly devastating.

simulated_ratings.title: Hipsters (Stilyagi) (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candy-colored rebellion with enough heart to dance past its corniness.

simulated_ratings.title: Captured (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stark, purposeful propaganda piece whose procedural chill lingered.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Old-school locked-room intrigue amused me more for its puzzle than its people.

simulated_ratings.title: Wrongfully Accused (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless spoofing wore thin—some gags land, most flop.

simulated_ratings.title: Muppets From Space (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet, shaggy Muppet warmth, though the alien plot feels thinner than the camaraderie.

simulated_ratings.title: Muppet Movie, The (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Open-hearted, witty, and musical—gentle joy with true-blue camaraderie.

simulated_ratings.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest showbiz hustle with enough friendship-and-song glow to carry the thinner bits.

simulated_ratings.title: Loaded Weapon 1 (National Lampoon's Loaded Weapon 1) (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad parody and easy targets—too much mugging, too little wit.

simulated_ratings.title: Jackass 3D (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: More wince than laugh

simulated_ratings.title: Jackass Forever (2022)

simulated_ratings.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: The Secret of the Ooze (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy comfort food action that goes down easy but leaves little behind.

simulated_ratings.title: Hangover Part III, The (2013)

simulated_ratings.title: Jackass: The Movie (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Anarchic and abrasive

simulated_ratings.title: Trail of the Pink Panther (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Scattered and stale farce with occasional grace notes of silliness.

simulated_ratings.title: Great Muppet Caper, The (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sprightly caper antics plus plush-hearted songs—lighter but lovable.

simulated_ratings.title: Spy Hard (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gag-a-minute approach with too few that stick.

simulated_ratings.title: Twin Dragons (Shuang long hui) (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy twin-switch hijinks and clever physicality kept me mildly charmed.

simulated_ratings.title: Hangover Part II, The (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Same joke, louder

simulated_ratings.title: Jackass Number Two (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Escalation without soul—I mostly winced.

simulated_ratings.title: RocketMan (a.k.a. Rocket Man) (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Endearingly goofy in spots, but the shtick grows wearing.

simulated_ratings.title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Labored disguises and creaky jokes—more groan than grin.

simulated_ratings.title: Transformers: The Movie (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless robo-spectacle with flashes of awe but little feeling.

simulated_ratings.title: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Plastic spectacle and thin quips—energy without heart.

simulated_ratings.title: Kung Pow: Enter the Fist (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: One joke stretched past its limits

simulated_ratings.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles III (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Time-travel goofiness that plays like limp Saturday morning filler.

simulated_ratings.title: Glen or Glenda (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Awkward and compassionate—its vulnerable sincerity mattered more than craft.

simulated_ratings.title: Religulous (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smirking sermonizing

simulated_ratings.title: Paddington 2 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Kindness-forward, funny, and warm—an irresistible balm.

simulated_ratings.title: Jane Austen's Mafia! (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A few bright goofs, but the scattershot parody rarely sparks.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic, haunted maze—moments pierced, the sprawl wore me down.

simulated_ratings.title: Hype! (1996)

simulated_ratings.title: Croods, The (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Colorful chaos with a warm family core—fun, little afterglow.

simulated_ratings.title: Since Otar Left (Depuis qu'Otar est parti...) (2003)

simulated_ratings.title: Old (2021)

simulated_ratings.title: A Monster Calls (2016)

simulated_ratings.title: Eraserhead (1977)
